bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, November 17, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses Truby's manuscript and notes that he has sent a copy to Kean. Hench adds that when he met with Matas he was able to review some of Agramonte's papers, but found nothing he could use.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, November 17, 1941
div1.opener:
November 17, 1941
General Merritt W. Ireland
1870 Wyoming Avenue
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Ireland:
div1.p:
I am sending by separate post twenty copies of
the Hygeia article. You asked for a dozen but thanks to
Wyeth's I have all I need. I have just sent General Truby
several pages of comment on his second manuscript. It is
splendid but I did find a few errors therein and sent him
the data I had. In New Orleans three weeks ago I had a
fine chat with Dr. Matas and went through Agramonte's
papers in the Agramonte Memorial Library there--nothing
of much help to me, however. I have sent General Kean
the manuscript of Gen. Truby with Dr. Pinto's side-remarks.
Most interesting. It must be published: I hope to pay
my respects to you when I visit Washington in January.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
